docs.lead_paragraph: The commercials begin like ordinary 30-second public service announcements. On the screen is a familiar scene like a man and woman in an office or people in a hurry on a busy sidewalk or a couple sitting at the kitchen table. The actors begin talking to each other about literacy or drugs or drunken driving or breast cancer. Or in some cases an offstage narrator talks about the problem.

headline.main: TV Ads by Congressional Wives Are a Sweet Deal for All Involved

docs.abstract: National Assn of Broadcasters is airing series of television commercials dealing with major social problems in which Congressional wives express opinions; commercials give television stations opportunity to engage in public service, and to fill empty time for which commercials have not been sold; represents risk-free way for members of Congress to keep names before public, benefit not avaliable to potential challengers; allow assn to quietly ingratiate itself further with lawmakers (M)

docs.lead_paragraph: An Arizona fertility clinic says it will destroy hundreds of frozen embryos if the donors do not claim them, a move experts say may be the first time a clinic in the United States has announced such plans. The clinic, the Arizona Institute of Reproductive Medicine, ran an advertisement last month in The Arizona Republic that began, ''If you feel you have embryos or sperms stored with Arizona Institute of Reproductive Medicine, please contact us immediately,'' and warned that all unclaimed specimens would be destroyed as of July 15.

headline.main: Clinic Plans to Destroy Unclaimed Embryos

docs.abstract: Arizona fertility clinic says it will destroy hundreds of frozen embryos if donors do not claim them, a move experts say may be first time a clinic in United States has announced such plans; clinic is Arizona Institute of Reproductive Medicine (S)

docs.lead_paragraph: The woman waiting for her abortion is 20 years old, a college student, wan and pretty, with long black hair and glasses. She arrives for her appointment promptly at 10 A.M., neatly dressed in pressed jeans and loafers, but her voice is shaking a little when she signs in at the front desk and her shoulders stay hunched, in what might be shyness or self-protection. She follows the nurse-practitioner into the examining room and lies down without being asked. During the exam, she winces and cries, making hardly a sound. But afterward, sitting up, her fingers laced together in her lap, she is almost talkative. ''Did you think about maybe keeping the baby or giving it up for adoption?'' the nurse-practitioner asks kindly. ''Yes,'' says the young woman, ''but I knew I didn't want to do that. My parents are having all kinds of financial difficulties. I know they'd want me to finish school.'' Besides, she says, her voice a little stronger now, though her sentences still end in that questioning upward lilt of late adolescence, ''I want to finish school. I don't want to work in a 7-Eleven all my life.'' And, after a long pause: ''I want to have kids someday, but I want to be able to take care of them so they won't be miserable.'' When the nurse asks if she has been using birth control, she says yes, she's on the pill, but she doesn't take it all that regularly. ''My boyfriend and I want to try that injection -- Depo-Provera? -- 'cause the pill makes me sick.'' So far, there is nothing especially unusual about the young woman's story. What is unusual is the kind of abortion she will have today. For quite personal reasons, she has opted for a new method with enormous political consequences. At 10:30 A.M., she sits down with a counselor, a chatty ex-schoolteacher, to hear about the procedure she is about to undertake as part of a clinical trial. Then a nurse guides her into another room, points her to the only chair and gives her a cup of water and a tablet of mifepristone -- better known as RU-486, or the French abortion pill. ''Here goes!'' the young woman says. She knows there is no turning back once she takes the pill. It will begin to work right away, blocking the effects of her body's progesterone, a hormone needed for the fertilized egg to sustain itself in the wall of her uterus.
docs.abstract: Margaret Talbott article on clinical US trials of mifepristone--better known as RU-486, the French abortion pill, which Danco Group plans to manufacture and market for general public by the end of 1999; says pill may well reconfigure the politics and perception of abortion in America, increasing the number of doctors willing to perform abortions, making it much harder for anti-abortion activitists to harass doctors and patients, increasing the frequency of early abortions and thus making abortion more socially acceptable; photos (L)

docs.lead_paragraph: Magrieta Manus and her husband, Bastiaan, have lived and worked on the same vineyard here for more than 40 years, making do with their nine children in two dilapidated rooms set on such a steep hill that their rocky, slanted dirt floor is usually damp from the rain. They work in the fields for less than $18 a week and, until two years ago, when the farm changed hands, they were given free wine under a system started centuries ago to addict laborers to alcohol and keeping them working for virtually nothing.

headline.main: Workers' Free Wine Ends, But South Africans Still Pay

docs.abstract: Alcohol abuse among South Africa's farm laborers and vineyard workers continues to be a problem; under system started centuries ago, workers were given free wine to addict them to alcohol, keeping them working for virtually nothing; system has been illegal for decades and is now publicly repudidated by wine industry, which is very conscious of its image and of past mistakes; some surveys suggest that 20 percent of farms in Western Cape Province still use system; but experts say that end of old system is ushering in new set of hardships, and new research shows an alarming rate of fetal alcohol syndrome in workers' children; photos; maps (L)

docs.lead_paragraph: Mondays may be tough, but the first week of a month can be a killer, a study of American death rates appearing in Thursday's New England Journal of Medicine found. The study, which examined records from 1983 to 1988, found that the combined death rate from substance abuse, suicide, accidents and homicide typically jumped 14 percent during the first week of each month compared with the last seven days of the previous month.

headline.main: Deaths Rise at Start of Month, Study Shows

docs.abstract: Study of American death rates appearing in New England Journal of Medicine finds combined death rate from substance abuse, suicide, accidents and homicide typically jumps 14 percent during first week of each month compared with last seven days of previous month; researchers at University of California at San Diego note disparity is even higher among poor, suggesting link to monthly benefit checks that arrive at start of month (M)
